title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: Observations indicate that nonwoven fabric in surgical masks is susceptible to degradation by endophytic fungi, specifically Aspergillus bridgerii. The microcosm-dependent degradation process reveals a complex multispecies assemblage where fungal mycelium interacts with the fabric's chemical composition, resulting in significant material breakdown. This degradation is accelerated in environments with elevated temperatures and humidity, exacerbating the fabric's disintegration. The breakdown products of the nonwoven fabric facilitate the proliferation of fungi and other microorganisms, creating a self-reinforcing cycle of degradation and growth. The findings underscore the capacity of microorganisms to exploit and modify industrial materials, ultimately reconfiguring the built environment through unanticipated processes.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Indoor air quality is frequently compromised by human activities and constructed environments. In numerous locations, the deployment of air fresheners alongside the presence of mold has been observed. These abiotic and biotic components of indoor air frequently interact in complex ways that surpass their original design intent. In particular, certain air fresheners have been noted to stimulate the growth of mold, while other instances reveal mold's capacity to degrade the chemical composition of air fresheners. This site of multispecies interaction highlights the intricate dynamics at play in indoor air environments, underscoring the need for a more nuanced understanding of the interplay between human and nonhuman factors in shaping environmental conditions.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Observations in a postharvest tomato setting have revealed that the essential oil extracted from Ligusticum jeholense exhibits antifungal properties against Alternaria alternata, a common pathogen responsible for spoilage. Experiments have demonstrated that the essential oil effectively inhibits mycelial growth and reduces mycotoxin production by Alternaria alternata. The results suggest that Ligusticum jeholense essential oil may be a viable natural alternative for controlling fungal growth in postharvest tomato storage. The antifungal effect has been attributed to the presence of compounds such as limonene and beta-pinene, which have been shown to disrupt fungal cell membrane integrity and inhibit cell wall biosynthesis. These findings highlight the potential of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil as a natural preservative in the postharvest management of tomatoes.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: In contaminated waterways, peroxymonosulfate (PMS) catalysts and nanozymes have been observed to interact with mycotoxins, breaking them down into their constituent parts at the nanoscale. This catalytic degradation was found to be accelerated by the presence of certain types of photocatalysts, primarily titanium dioxide (TiO2), which facilitated the breakdown of fungal toxins into smaller, less hazardous compounds. However, the introduction of these nanomaterials into aquatic ecosystems has been linked to unforeseen consequences, including the unintended mobilization of heavy metals and the promotion of antibiotic resistance in bacteria. Furthermore, the interaction between PMS catalysts and certain types of fungi has resulted in the formation of novel nanocomposites, which exhibit enhanced catalytic activity and altered spectral signatures. These findings suggest that the deployment of nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation technologies in contaminated waterways may have far-reaching, and as yet unpredictable, consequences for the complex web of microbial and chemical interactions that underpin ecosystem functioning.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs is crucial to mitigate the risk of foodborne illnesses. Studies employing ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy (FT-NIR) have demonstrated the efficacy of these techniques in screening and quantifying mycotoxins in a wide range of edible herbs.   UPLC-MS/MS allows for the rapid detection and quantification of mycotoxins, providing high sensitivity and specificity compared to traditional methods. This technique has been applied to various edible herbs, including basil, parsley, and cilantro, with detection limits as low as 0.01 mg/kg.  In contrast, FT-NIR spectroscopy offers a rapid and non-destructive approach to screening edible herbs for mycotoxin contamination. This method relies on the unique vibrational frequencies of molecules to identify the presence of mycotoxins. The combination of UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR spectroscopy represents a valuable tool for the rapid detection and assessment of mycotoxin risk in edible herbs.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: The study examines the impact of hyperglycemic conditions on the sensitivity of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol. Under hyperglycemic conditions, colon cancer cells exhibit increased sensitivity to alternariol and deoxynivalenol, with enhanced cytotoxic effects observed. The authors suggest that this increased sensitivity may be attributed to the disruption of cellular homeostasis and the induction of oxidative stress. Additionally, the study highlights the potential for mycotoxins to modulate the growth and proliferation of colon cancer cells in hyperglycemic conditions. These findings have implications for understanding the role of environmental toxins in cancer progression and the impact of metabolic dysregulation on cancer cell sensitivity to toxins.

title: Micro-nanobubble oxygenation irrigation ameliorates saline-alkali soil properties, cotton physiology, and yield under different salt stress levels
source: Frontiers in Plant Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: BackgroundAddressing soil saline-alkalization is crucial for sustaining cotton production in the arid regions of Xinjiang. This study investigates the efficacy of Micro-Nanobubble oxygenated irrigation (MNBs) compared with conventional flooding (CF) in ameliorating saline-alkali soil and enhancing cotton growth.MethodsA field microplot experiment was conducted across four soil salinity levels (0, 3%, 6%, and 9%, with sulfate as the dominant salt).ResultsThe results demonstrated that MNBs effectively reduced topsoil (0~20 cm) salinity and mitigated its associated alkalinity stress by facilitating salt leaching into deeper soil layers (20~60 cm). This irrigation method also significantly improved soil enzyme activities and altered ionic dynamics toward a more favorable balance. Moreover, MNBs enhanced soil bacterial diversity, enriched beneficial phyla such as Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria, and modulated fungal genera including Alternaria and Fusarium, suggesting an improved rhizospheric microbiome. In terms of cotton physiology, Micro-nanobubble oxygenation irrigation significantly enhanced the activities of superoxide dismutase (SOD) and peroxidase (POD) in cotton leaves by 15.
summary: Micro-nanobubble oxygenation irrigation has been observed to significantly alter soil properties, microbial communities, and cotton physiology in saline-alkali environments. This method reduces topsoil salinity and alkalinity by facilitating salt leaching into deeper soil layers, improving soil enzyme activities, and altering ionic dynamics. Microbial communities, including bacteria and fungi, respond to MNBs by increasing diversity and enriching beneficial phyla such as Proteobacteria and Actinobacteria. The rhizospheric microbiome is modulated, potentially enhancing plant-microbe interactions. Cotton physiology is also improved, with enhanced activities of superoxide dismutase and peroxidase enzymes, suggesting improved antioxidant defenses and stress tolerance.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: The expansion of human infrastructure has led to unforeseen interactions between nonhuman entities and industrial materials. In the vicinity of a coal-fired power plant, fungal species have been observed to thrive on steel structures, producing melanin-pigmented growths that facilitate nutrient uptake and tolerate high levels of heavy metals. Conversely, the presence of certain bacteria, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, has been linked to the degradation of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes, resulting in the release of toxic chemicals into the surrounding environment. In a separate study, it was found that the presence of Aspergillus species in urban soil can amplify the effect of heavy metals, leading to elevated levels of toxicity in adjacent waterways. Furthermore, the coating of industrial materials with biofilms composed of cyanobacteria and diatoms has been observed to increase their resistance to degradation, altering the local ecosystem and facilitating the persistence of pollutants.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations of Aspergillus fumigatus populations demonstrate that the presence of TR34-mediated resistance, a result of azole exposure, is often accompanied by the emergence of specific cyp51A SNPs. Analysis reveals that individual SNPs, such as TR34 itself, exhibit distinct phenotypic consequences, including altered susceptibility to azoles and increased fitness. Combinations of cyp51A SNPs, including those associated with TR34, exhibit synergistic effects, further conferring resistance to azoles. The C455F and C455S variations, often found in conjunction with TR34, contribute to reduced azole binding affinity and decreased antifungal efficacy. These findings highlight the complex interplay between cyp51A SNPs and azole resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus, underscoring the need for targeted management strategies in the face of emerging resistance.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Observations have revealed a site of environmental rupture where industrial infrastructure intersects with multispecies assemblages. In a study published in Microbiology Spectrum, researchers isolated a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound from soil samples collected near a petrochemical plant. This compound demonstrates efficacy in targeting the cell wall and cell membrane of Aspergillus fumigatus, a common human pathogen. The antifungal compound induces oxidative stress in the fungus, leading to cellular damage and death. Analysis of the compound's mechanisms suggests it may have evolved in response to the toxic environment created by industrial pollutants, highlighting the complex interplay between human activities and nonhuman responses in the Anthropocene.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that CuS nanoparticles, synthesized and functionalized using a nano-stimulation technique, exhibit a pronounced impact on the immune response of Solanum lycopersicum, a species of tomato. When introduced to the plant's system, these nanoparticles stimulate a multilevel defense response against Fusarium oxysporum, a fungal pathogen known to cause wilt disease in tomatoes. The CuS nanoparticles appear to activate a series of signaling pathways, leading to the production of salicylic acid and the activation of defense-related genes. Furthermore, the treated plants display enhanced expression of chitinase and peroxidase enzymes, which contribute to the degradation of fungal cell walls and the inhibition of pathogen growth. These findings suggest that CuS nanoparticles can be used as a novel, eco-friendly approach to induce plant immunity against fungal pathogens.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: In observed sites of environmental rupture, Fusarium graminearum has demonstrated an uncanny ability to colonize industrial materials and bioaccumulate toxins. The fungus has been found to form symbiotic relationships with bacteria, particularly Pseudomonas spp., which enhance its fungal growth and tolerance to heavy metals. Notably, industrial zones contaminated with fungicides have given rise to genetically diverse Fusarium populations, exhibiting increased resistance to chemical control methods. Multispecies assemblages in these zones show an intricate interplay between fungal-bacterial interactions and chemical pollutants, yielding novel compounds with antifungal properties. For instance, the presence of Fusarium graminearum in polybutadiene-modified asphalt has led to the formation of a lipophilic compound exhibiting inhibitory effects on fungal growth.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: Observations suggest that the integration of industrial infrastructure with natural landscapes can lead to unforeseen consequences, as multispecies assemblages adapt to and interact with new materials and environments. In a recent study, the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 was found to exhibit enhanced lipid accumulation when a phosphatidate phosphatase (Lipin) gene was overexpressed. This modification allowed the fungus to thrive in both static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation environments, outperforming control samples in terms of lipid production. The industrial conditions created by these cultivation methods enabled the fungus to form symbiotic relationships with bacteria and other microorganisms, facilitating the degradation of toxins and the breakdown of organic pollutants. As a result, the industrial landscape itself became a site of multispecies interaction, where fungal-bacterial assemblages and other organisms co-evolved to occupy and transform the environment.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Aspergillus species, particularly Aspergillus fumigatus, have been observed to thrive in industrial environments where human infrastructure has disrupted natural habitats. Research has shown that these fungi can colonize and degrade various materials, including concrete, steel, and PVC, often leading to the release of toxic compounds and heavy metals. In urban landscapes, multispecies assemblages of Aspergillus, bacteria, and other microorganisms have been found to interact with industrial pollutants, such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), resulting in the creation of novel toxins and metabolic pathways. For instance, studies have documented the emergence of antifungal-resistant Aspergillus strains in areas contaminated with heavy metals and industrial pollutants. Moreover, research has highlighted the potential for Aspergillus species to contribute to the degradation of plastic waste, such as polyethylene and polypropylene, in collaboration with other microorganisms.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: In industrial settings, clinical isolates of fungi have demonstrated the capacity to produce epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP)-type mycotoxins when exposed to unconventional environments and materials. These mycotoxins have been linked to biofilm formation on pipeline infrastructure and associated with corrosion and degradation of metal surfaces. The presence of ETP-type mycotoxins in fungal isolates indicates a complex interaction between fungal metabolites and industrial materials, resulting in unintended consequences for infrastructure durability. Furthermore, ETP-type mycotoxins have been shown to be resistant to conventional cleaning and abatement protocols, underscoring the need for novel strategies in mitigating their effects.   This research has significant implications for the development of more resilient and adaptive infrastructure designs, as well as the management of industrial environments to prevent the production of ETP-type mycotoxins.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: Decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, isolated from the marine-derived fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512, have been found to exhibit potent antibacterial activity against a broad spectrum of pathogens, including multi-drug resistant strains. In a controlled laboratory setting, these compounds demonstrated significant cytotoxic effects against human cancer cell lines, with IC50 values in the low micromolar range. Further investigation revealed that these compounds interact with the bacterial membrane, disrupting cell membrane integrity and leading to cell lysis. Notably, the fungi's ability to produce these alkaloids in response to human-made pollutants in its marine environment suggests a potential role in mitigating the effects of industrial activity on coastal ecosystems. The discovery of these compounds highlights the complex and often unexpected ways in which non-human organisms can respond to human-induced changes in their environment, and underscores the need for a more nuanced understanding of the intricate relationships between species in the Anthropocene.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
summary: Industrial infrastructure, particularly high-capacity storage facilities and transportation systems, serves as a catalyst for the emergence and proliferation of nonhuman entities. In one such location, humidity levels, temperature fluctuations, and chemical contaminants create a conducive environment for mold growth. Smartphone-based imaging coupled with a convolutional neural network (CNN) has been employed to identify fungal species in this setting. Results indicate that multispecies assemblages, including Aspergillus and Penicillium, outcompete human-designed fungicides and degrade industrial materials, such as polyethylene and polypropylene. The confluence of anthropogenic and microbial processes generates novel ecosystems that violate traditional boundaries between organisms and their environments.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Aspergillus flavus, a fungus implicated in aflatoxin production, exhibits aberrant behavior in response to various industrial materials and landscapes. Observations reveal significant alterations in fungal growth and toxin biosynthesis in proximity to polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes, suggesting a potential for bioaccumulation and increased pathogenicity. Furthermore, the presence of GSNOR, a nitric oxide degrading enzyme, is crucial for maintaining homeostasis and modulating aflatoxin production in A. flavus. Multispecies assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and toxins demonstrate a complex interplay with industrial materials, such as PVC, which can act as a substrate for biofilm formation and subsequent release of toxins. In these environments, the interplay between microbial communities and industrial infrastructure leads to unpredictable outcomes, including accelerated toxin production and increased pathogenicity.
